[Petruchio], [localtime://2007-06-24 03:06:12]
I did some homework on this one... necessarily, as I'm not actually a big fan of any of the Trek series. IMDB has a [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0060028/fullcredits#cast|master list].

My favorite crew member from the original Star Trek: There are actually a fair number of consistent minor crew members... sort of. The actor Eddie Paskey, for instance, appears in 59 episodes, and at one point is identified as "Lieutenant Leslie". According to [http://www.eddiepaskey.com/Mr_leslie_facts.htm|this reference]:

He can be seen in nearly every episode from the first two seasons as well as a few from the third. He played many scenes as a "red shirt", usually the first to die when exploring a planet. He is the only one though, to have died in one episode ("Obsession") and returned in the next! This was due to to the fact that a scene from the script that was never shot indicated that the victims were brought back to life!
The same reference notes that he has "been seen wearing a gold, blue, and red shirt", and that at one point "He even played 'Mr. Connors', one of McCoy's medical assistants!"

So it's kind of hard to figure out how often Paskey's appearances were Lt. Leslie, and how often they were some other token crewman (possibly slated for death). I decided, therefore, to keep it simple, and let the monks mention oddball favorites in the comments.

I do think "the computer" is an interesting idea, but I don't have a good alternative for "crew" that would let the computer through and keep the rest of the flood out.

Heh. I'd suggest that a prominent part of [tye]-nature involves being subtle in a way that others don't follow. With this poll, for instance, the joke is the suggestion that nobody actually learns to cook except by watching television. A fair number of those who responded, however, complained of missing options, and a fair number of the others got the idea, but seemed more inclined to just talk about how they actually learned to cook.

In a sense, that's not a bad thing. People are voting, and talking; like party games, polls are supposed to give people something to talk about. I do think that the more general the topic, however, the easier it is to talk about. Possibly a straight "How I Learned to Cook" poll would have made for more interesting conversation.

The point that the poll slants heavily towards American TV is fair. That didn't strike me as I read it either, though. Overall, though, it's really not a bad poll at all.
